mdRecord.dcterms:description: The site includes the reconstructed blast furnace, forge, rolling mill, shear, slitter and quarter-ton drop hammer. The facility is powered by seven large waterwheels, some of which are rigged to work in tandem with huge wooden gears connecting them. Archaeological excavations conducted 1948 uncovered the major manufacturing units of the Iron Works, including the foundations of buildings, remains of the blast furnace, holding ponds, and canal, a 500-pound hammer used in the forge, and a waterwheel that powered the bellows for the blast furnace, along with its wheel pit. The Boston architecture firm of Perry, Shaw & Hepburn, Kehoe & Dean was hired to reconstruct the Iron Works, which opened September 18, 1954. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saugus_Iron_Works_National_Historic_Site [work]
